title: ELEVATIONAL GRADIENTS IN MAMMALS: SPECIAL ISSUE
abstract: It is widely accepted that tropical lowland rain forest holds the greatest diversity of organisms, and it is often implied that this general pattern is also true for virtually all individual higherlevel taxa. Standardized elevational transect surveys of non-flying small mammals (Insectivora and Rodentia) on geologically old, speciesrich islands in the Philippines consistently show maximum diversity and relative abundance in upper montane/lower mossy forest at 1500-2200 m, often exceeding lowland species richness and relative abundance by a factor of three or more. 2 On mountains where maximum elevation exceeds 2000 m, there is a decline in species richness above about 1500-2000 m, yielding a curvilinear pattern of species richness along the elevational gradient. The peak in species richness occurs at the area of transition from montane to mossy forest, which is also the point at which rainfall probably peaks. In parallel with species richness, relative abundance of small mammals in the Philippines also increases from the lowlands to 1500-2200 m, increasing by a factor from two to 10. 3 Twelve hypotheses concerning patterns of diversity along elevational gradients, plus the null hypothesis, are evaluated. The null hypothesis of no variation and the hypotheses that maximum diversity is in the lowlands, that diversity is highest in areas of least perturbation, and that diversity increases with increasing area, are rejected. There is weak or ambiguous support for the hypotheses that diversity is greatest in areas of community interdigitation, that diversity is highest in the area of highest productivity, that diversity is correlated with habitat complexity, and that diversity is correlated with habitat diversity. There is strongest support for the hypotheses that diversity is correlated with annual rainfall, with total abundance of individuals in the community, with food resource diversity, with areas of reduced competition from other organisms, and with areas characterized by high rates of speciation. 4 Causality is difficult to evaluate because many hypotheses make non-exclusive predictions, they probably represent non-independent aspects of causal factors (in other words, there is much interaction among the processes highlighted by the various hypotheses), and they represent the range from proximate to ultimate and from descriptive to causal. All the hypotheses probably represent phenomena that exist in nature, but few (or none) represent phenomena found in all taxa. The primary challenge in the future will not be simply to accept or reject individual hypotheses, but rather to determine the circumstances under which the various causal factors are most important, how they interact, and how they can be combined into a more comprehensive and general multi-factorial model.

body_text.text: Geographical variation in biological diversity is one of the most conspicuous patterns in biology. Developing an understanding of that variation has played a central role in biology for a century and a half (e.g. Darwin, 1859; Wallace, 1878; Pianka, 1966; MacArthur, 1972; Cody & Diamond, 1975; Schall & Pianka, 1978; McCoy & Connor, 1980; Brown, 1988 Brown, , 1995 Ricklefs & Schluter, 1993; Rosenzweig, 1995; Brown & Lomolino, 1998) . In recent years, the need to document and understand patterns of biological diversity has taken on new urgency as the current threats to biological diversity have become more widely recognized (e.g. Soulé, 1986; Wilson, 1988; Gore, 1992; Myers, 1993; Quammen, 1996) .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Much recent research has focused on patterns of diversity in naturally and artificially fragmented habitats, under the conceptual rubric of island biogeography, and good progress has been made in increasing our understanding of the processes of colonization and extinction (e.g. MacArthur & Wilson, 1967; Williamson, 1981; Case & Cody, 1983; Harris, 1984; Heaney & Patterson, 1986; Schafer, 1990; Laurence & Bierregaard, 1997; Brown & Lomolino, 1998; Whittaker, 1998; Lomolino, 2000) . Much less attention has been given in recent years to variation in species richness in non-fragmented habitats, especially along elevational gradients, even though montane ecosystems usually support the highest local concentrations of species within a biotic region, especially in the tropics (Kikkawa & Williams, 1971; Terborgh, 1977; Beehler, 1981; Graham, 1983 Graham, , 1990 Heaney et al. , 1989; McCoy, 1990; Rahbek, 1995) . Almost the only generally recognized aspect of variation along elevational gradients has been the virtually axiomatic claim that lowland tropical forest holds the maximum level of biological diversity (e.g. MacArthur, 1972, p. 199; Brown & Gibson, 1983: 502; Whitmore, 1984, p. 259; papers in Wilson, 1988; Patterson et al. , 1996 Patterson et al. , , 1998 , although some authors have noted the paucity of reliable data about elevational patterns (Colwell & Hurtt, 1994; Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 Brown & Lomolino, 1998) .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In recent studies of small mammals in the Philippines (Goodman & Ingle, 1993; Heaney, 1986 Heaney, , 1993 Heaney, , 2000 Heaney et al. , 1989 Heaney et al. , , 1998 Heaney et al. , , 1999 Heaney et al. , , 2000 Heaney & Rickart, 1990; Rickart et al. , , 1993 Ingle & Heaney, 1992; Musser & Heaney, 1992; Utzurrum, 1992; Ingle, 1993; Oliver et al. , 1993; Peterson & Heaney, 1993; Rickart, 1993) , my colleagues and I have sought to document patterns in the abundance and distribution of small mammals as a means to understand both their ecology and evolution and to develop programmes for their conservation. Our efforts to date with this poorly known fauna have focused on documenting general ecological and evolutionary patterns and on seeking potential explanations that can then be investigated in detail. In this process, we have found patterns of diversity that we did not anticipate, and these have impact on both conceptual models of evolutionary biogeography and on appropriate actions concerning the conservation of the fauna.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this paper, empirical data are summarized that document elevational changes in species richness of non-volant small mammals on several geologically old, species-rich islands in the Philippines. It is not the purpose of this paper to review exhaustively all hypotheses of factors that influence patterns of diversity. Rather, its purpose is to use the data as an opportunity to review the range of available hypotheses, to point out briefly their conspicuous strengths and weaknesses, and to draw preliminary conclusions regarding the most likely factors that influence patterns of diversity within the organisms under study. As noted by Brown (1988 Brown ( , 2001 , Rahbek (1995 Rahbek ( , 1997 , Brown & Lomolino (1998) , and Lomolino (2000) , the hypotheses are quite diverse; some deal with proximate causes, others ultimate, some descriptive and some causal. The paper concludes with an evaluation of the utility of the hypotheses, with the intent of providing direction and focus for future research.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Wet tropical forests in mountainous portions of South-east Asia are generally divided into four primary elevationally-based habitat types: lowland, montane (= lower montane of some authors), mossy (= upper montane and cloud forest of some authors) and subalpine (Whitmore, 1984) . The elevational range of each habitat type is determined by local conditions of mean annual temperature and precipitation (Frahm & Gradstein, 1991) . On tall mountains (>3000 m), lowland forest dominated by the tree family Dipterocarpaceae (dipterocarps) usually extends up to about 1200 -1600 m, where it grades into montane forest. Montane forest, usually dominated by Fagaceae (oaks), Lauraceae (cinnamon), Myrtaceae (myrtles) and Theaceae (camellias) extends from 1200 to 1600 m up to 1800-2400 m. Mossy or upper montane forest extends from its lower limit at about 1800-2400 m up to 2800-3000 m, and is dominated by Symplocaceae (alum tree relatives) and Myrsinaceae (ardisias); this zone then grades into subalpine forest, dominated by Ericaceae (heather and heath) and Myricaceae (bayberries) (2800 m to 3200 m) and subalpine scrub, usually dominated by Rhododendron and Vaccinium , from about 3200-3500 m (Whitmore, 1984; Ohsawa, 1990 Ohsawa, , 1991 Frahm & Gradstein, 1991) . There are no snow-or ice-capped peaks in South-east Asia.
body_text.section: Primary habitats of the study area

body_text.text: Bryophytes (mosses and liverworts) are often used as a conspicuous indicator of elevational zones; their growth is enhanced in conditions of low temperature and high light intensity. Mosses and liverworts have low biomass in lowland forest (less than 10 g/m 2 and less than 10% coverage on lower tree trunks), where light intensity at ground level averages 1% of daylight and temperatures are above 20 ° C. Bryophytes increase abruptly in montane forest (30-50 g/m 2 and 25-50% coverage), and increase sharply again at the lower edge of mossy forest (80-200 g/m 2 and 70-80% coverage), where they become a conspicuous part of the ground cover; in mossy forest, light intensity at ground level averages 20% of daylight. In tropical subalpine forests, where temperatures average 6-8 ° C and light intensity at the forest floor is up to 50% of daylight, bryophyte cover is often greater still, reaching 120-400 g/m 2 (Frahm & Gradstein, 1991) .
body_text.section: Primary habitats of the study area

body_text.text: On low mountains, these zones are depressed to low elevations; for example, the transition from lowland to montane forest on Mt Makiling, a 1143-m peak south of Manila on Luzon Island, is at about 1000 m (Brown, 1919) . This tendency for vegetational zones to occur lower on small mountains is known as the 'Massenerhebung' effect (Richards, 1952: 346-368; Grubb & Whitmore, 1966; Whitmore, 1984: 253; Frahm & Gradstein, 1991) .
body_text.section: Primary habitats of the study area

body_text.text: Although plant species diversity is typically highest in the lowlands (Whitmore, 1984: 249; Jacobs, 1988: 180) , most individual families show pronounced peaks in one of these zones, with many families confined to one or more of the upper zones (Ohsawa, 1990 (Ohsawa, , 1991 . Some elevationally widespread groups show pronounced midelevation peaks in species richness; ferns and orchids, for example, both peak at ca. 1500 m on Mt Kinabalu in Sabah, Malaysia (Parris et al. , 1992; Wood et al. , 1993) .
body_text.section: Primary habitats of the study area

body_text.text: The animal groups utilized in this study are speciose and easily sampled in South-east Asia; they include insectivores of the families Soricidae (shrews) and Erinaceidae (wood shrews or gymnures) and rodents of the family Muridae (rats and mice). These three families comprise 65 of the 111 species of native, non-flying land mammals known from the Philippines (Heaney, 1993; Heaney et al. , 1998) .
body_text.section: Study animals and sites

body_text.text: The locations of detailed elevational transect sites in the Philippines are shown in Fig. 1 . Mount Isarog is the highest peak in southern Luzon at nearly 2000 m; Mount Pangasugan on Leyte, at only 1150 m, is one of the highest on Leyte; and Mount Kitanglad on Mindanao, at nearly 2900 m, is one of the highest peaks in the Philippines. In each case we sampled only in primary forest (except at the lowest site on Mount Isarog), in the largest areas of forest that still exist. Vegetation along our transects consists of lowland dipterocarp forest, montane forest and mossy forest (Heaney et al. , 1989 (Heaney et al. , , 1999 Rickart et al. , , 1993 Rickart, 1993) , as defined above.
body_text.section: Study animals and sites

body_text.text: We measured species richness and relative abundance of small mammals in the Philippines directly by extensive trapping at all sites. Transects were located in areas that had the most extensive forest available; because historical records indicate no changes in the lowland forest mammal communities, we believe that recent extinctions played no part in determining the species richness patterns that are reported here. Individual sites were selected to represent the suite of natural habitats available along the elevational gradient, spaced as evenly along the transect as was practical, with intervening intervals of at least 200 m (except on Mt Kitanglad, which had three nearby but non-contiguous segments due to local topography; Heaney et al. , 1989 Heaney et al. , , 1999 Rickart et al. , , 1993 .
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Small mammals were caught in a mixture of Victor rat traps ( ≈ 75-80%) and National live traps ( ≈ 20-25%). Traps were baited late each afternoon with fresh fried coconut coated with peanut butter, or live earthworms. They were checked each morning soon after dawn and late each afternoon. Traps were placed 5-10 m apart; most (95%) were placed on the ground, but about 5% were placed above ground on fallen trees, horizontal branches or large vines. Individual Heaney, 1986) . traps were placed in lines of 20-40, and were left in place for 3 (usually) or 4 (rarely) days. Given lines were set at least 20 m apart, and given sites were sampled over the course of 8-18 days. Relative abundance of small mammals was estimated as the number of animals captured per 100 trap-nights, using 700-1900 trap-nights per site. Species-accumulation curves (Fig. 2) were used to determine the likelihood that all species had been sampled at given sites and transects (Heaney et al. , 1989 (Heaney et al. , , 1999 Rickart et al. , , 1993 . These species-accumulation curves indicate that, at any given site, the relative species richness was apparent by about 500 trapnights. Almost all species had been captured by 750 trap-nights at the majority of sites where more extensive sampling (1200-1900 trap-nights) was conducted, so we used 750 trap-nights as our minimum sampling effort. The 1550 m site on Mt Isarog was exceptional in its long lagtime required to approach an asymptote, as well as in its unexpectedly low relative abundance and other features . We inferred the presence of a species at a given elevation on a transect when that species was present at higher and lower elevations along the transect; such inferences accounted for less than 5% of the totals reported here (Fig. 3) .
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Species richness patterns of small mammals on Mindanao were estimated by two different means. The first of these was a detailed transect study conducted on Mt Kitanglad, Bukidnon Province, in 1992 and 1993, using the same methods as on Leyte and Luzon. The results of this study will be described in detail elsewhere; partial, preliminary results were presented by Rickart (1993) , and are summarized here. It should be noted that trapping efforts at the two uppermost sites on Mt Kitanglad were not standardized, and so relative abundance was not estimated for those two sites.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: For the second estimate of species richness patterns on Mindanao (Fig. 4) , our elevational transect data from Mt Kitanglad were combined with data summarized by Musser & Heaney (1992) , which includes all available elevational data on soricids, erinaceids and murids from published sources (Mearns, 1905; Hollister, 1913; Taylor, 1934; Hoogstraal, 1951; Sanborn, 1952; Musser, 1982a; 1982b) and unpublished specimen records in museum collections (American Museum of Natural History, Delaware Museum of Natural History, The Field Museum of Natural History, and US National Museum of Natural History), most of which were obtained prior to the extensive deforestation of Mindanao that began in the 1960s. This method has the advantage of providing data on low elevation forest, which was absent from our detailed transect on Mindanao, but probably tends to overestimate elevational ranges along any single transect (since many sites are lumped), and therefore may overestimate local (alpha) species richness at any given elevation.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Data from an elevational transect of small mammals on Negros Island are not included Heaney et al. , 1989) in this analysis because Negros has unique features that make it non-comparable with Leyte, Luzon and Mindanao. Negros is an oceanic island that is relatively young in geological age (perhaps as young as 250 000 years), and has a native small mammal fauna of only two species (Heaney, 1986 ; for current nomenclature see Heaney et al. , 1998) . The great majority of small mammals in primary forest on Negros are introduced commensal species: Suncus murinus , the Asian house shrew; Rattus exulans , the Polynesian rice rat; and R. tanezumi , the Asian house rat, formerly part of R. rattus (Musser & Carleton, 1993) . The three Philippine islands that are included in this analysis all have rich native faunas, developed over the more than 25 million years of their existence (Heaney, 1986; Hall, 1996 Hall, , 1998 . Comparisons between geologically young, depauperate islands and geologically older, species-rich islands will be published elsewhere.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Statistical analyses were conducted using NCSS 6.0 (Hintze, 1995) . Previous studies that have discussed mid-elevation (or mid-productivity) peaks in species richness have not included statistical analyses to document their claims of curvilinear relationships that peak at midelevations (e.g. McCoy, 1990; Parris et al. , 1992; Rosenzweig, 1992; Rosenzweig & Abramsky, 1993; Wood et al. , 1993; Olson, 1994; Rahbek, 1995) . I suspect that this is because analysis of curvilinear relationships is more fraught with difficulty than is linear regression analysis, especially when sample sizes are small, as is usually the case with transect studies. In this study the problem has been approached in a direct but somewhat simplistic fashion. For all relevant datasets, the relationship between species richness and elevation were evaluated by first using the LOWESS regression analysis procedure, which uses locally weighted sums of squares to identify the underlying trend in a dataset without requiring the specification of any given linear or polynomial model (Cleveland, 1979; Hintze, 1995) . If LOWESS analysis showed that a curvilinear relationship is present, polynomial regression was then used to determine the best fit among a first-order polynomial (i.e. linear; y = m x + b), a second-order (= quadratic) polynomial ( y = x 2 + m x + b) and a third-order (= cubic) polynomial ( y = x 3 + x 2 + m x + b) regression, where y = species richness, x = elevation, m = a variable describing the slope of the curve, and b = the y -intercept. The best fit was judged by comparison of the P -values and the r 2 values (Table 1 ; note that probability requirements are increasingly difficult to achieve with increasing polynomials).

body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Species richness of small mammals on Mt Pangasugan, Leyte, has been described in detail by Heaney et al . (1989) and Rickart et al . (1993) . The distribution of the five native species at four sites ( Fig. 3c ; Table 1 ) shows no discernable pattern. The lack of pattern may be associated with the small number of species (which is correlated with the small size of the island), the low height of the mountain (1150 m) and the small number of sampling sites (four). Because of the small number of sites, there are too few degrees of freedom to permit either a LOWESS analysis or second-or third-order polynomial regression analyses. Species richness on Mt Isarog, southern Luzon, has been described in detail by and Heaney et al . (1999) . The distribution of the eight native species at six sites (Fig. 3b) shows a progressive increase in species richness with increasing elevation, with a slight drop at the top. LOWESS analysis showed this pattern clearly ( Fig. 5b) . Although a linear regression of elevation and species richness was significant ( r 2 = 0.75, P = 0.03), a third-order polynomial provided a substantially better fit ( r 2 = 0.99, P = 0.02; Table 1 ). The overall pattern ( Fig. 3b ) is one of maximum diversity (all species present) near the top of the mountain (peak at 1966 m), with progressive attenuation with declining elevation. Species appear to fall into two groups: elevational generalists that are present at nearly all sites (three species) and highland species (five species) that do not occur below 1000 m, which is the transition area between lowland and montane forest .
body_text.section: Species richness patterns

body_text.text: Species richness on Mt Kitanglad, northern Mindanao was investigated in 1992 and 1993 (Rickart, 1993; see Methods) . The distribution of 11 native species at eight sites (Fig. 3a) shows a progressive increase in species richness from two species near the lower limit of forest at 1000 m to nine species at 2250 m, and a decline thereafter to five species at the site just below the peak. There appears to be one elevational generalist (Crocidura beatus); one lowland species (Crunomys melanius) found only at or below 1600 m; one species in lowland and montane forest (Rattus everetti); four species in montane forest, which extends from 1600 to 2250 m (Apomys insignis, Batomys salomonseni, C. suncoides and Limnomys sibuanus); three species (Podogymnura truei, A. hylocetes and Tarsomys apoensis) that occur above 1800 or 1900 m, which varies from montane forest (without lowland elements) to prime mossy forest; and one species (Tarsomys sp. A) that occurs at and above 2250 m, which is the elevation at which mossy forest elements first appear. Maximum species richness occurs at 2250 m, which is the area of transition from montane to mossy forest. LOWESS analysis showed a clear curvilinear pattern (Fig. 5b) . A linear regression was not significant (r 2 = 0.36; P = 0.16). A second-order polynomial regression fell slightly short of significance (r 2 = 0.73; P = 0.07; Table 1 ), but yielded the highest combination of r 2 and P-values among first, second or thirdorder analyses (Table 1) .
body_text.section: Species richness patterns

body_text.text: The general summary of elevational ranges of all 14 species of small mammals on Mindanao (Fig. 4 ) yields a pattern similar to that for the Mt Kitanglad transect study. Roughly three species are lowland species (1600 m and below), two are montane specialists (roughly 1600-2250 m), four are mossy forest specialists (from 1800 m or more to near the peak), three are elevational generalists (from near sea level to near the peak) and two are montane and mossy forest generalists (1600 m to near the peak). There is much variation, however, and it is apparent that there are no sharp elevational boundaries between communities when all Mindanao records are grouped in this fashion, as might be expected when geographically diverse records are combined. LOWESS analysis showed a clear curvilinear pattern (Fig. 5b ) that is very similar to that on Mt Kitanglad. The first-and secondorder regressions of species richness on elevation are not significant, but the third-order polynomial is significant (r 2 = 0.97; P = 0.04; Table 1 ). It should be noted that, relative to the transect data, this dataset has the advantage of including a larger number of records gathered over many years and thus probably represents a more general picture of patterns in the native Mindanao mammal fauna than do the transect data. Conversely, the general data set has the disadvantage of lumping together records from mountains with different heights, different amounts of rainfall and different levels of disturbance. This probably exaggerates the degree of overlap that actually exists between various species, and therefore inflates the estimates of total species richness at any given elevation.
body_text.section: Species richness patterns

body_text.text: When all four patterns of species richness are compared ( Fig. 5 ), two shared elements are apparent. First, the elevation at which each type of vegetation occurs is strongly influenced by the maximum elevation of the transect; some components of mossy forest, for example, are moderately well developed at 950 m on Leyte, but mossy forest does not appear until 1550 m on our Luzon transect and at 2250 m and above on the transect on Mindanao. Thus, if the curves shown in Fig. 5a were redrawn to standardize on the basis of habitat rather than elevation, there would be greater similarity. This suggests that features of the habitat may be as or more important in determining these patterns than is elevation itself.
body_text.section: Species richness patterns

body_text.text: The second shared element is the curvilinear nature of the relationship between elevation and species richness (Fig. 5b ). In the two datasets drawn from areas with elevations that exceed 2000 m, LOWESS analysis shows that there is a strongly apparent curvilinear relationship, and at the one transect (Luzon) where maximum elevation is greater than 1200 m but less than 2000 m, there is evidence of the increase phase, but little of the decrease phase. Only at the study area where maximum elevation is less than 1200 m (Leyte) is there no significant variation.
body_text.section: Species richness patterns

body_text.text: Relative abundance data are available only from the three transects (Fig. 6 ), and at one of these (Mt Kitanglad, Mindanao) we lack standardized estimates from above 2250 m (see Methods). Estimates indicate that the relative abundance at the lowest and highest sites on a given transect differ by a factor of from two to 10, always highest at or near the top. The correlation between relative abundance and elevation is not significant for the Leyte (r 2 = 0.92, P > 0.05; n = 4) or Luzon (r 2 = 0.53, P > 0.05; n = 6) transects, but was significant for the Mindanao transect (r 2 = 0.93, P < 0.05; n = 5). Taking all three sites together, there is a significant positive correlation between relative abundance and elevation (r 2 = 0.58, P < 0.05; n = 15).
body_text.section: Relative abundance patterns

body_text.text: The correlation between species richness and relative abundance ( Fig. 7) is not significant for the Leyte (r 2 = 0.38, P > 0.05; n = 4) or Luzon (r 2 = 0.34, P > 0.05; n = 5) transects taken separately [as noted by , at one apparently anomalous site on the Luzon transect, the first of two periods of sampling yielded species richness and relative abundance values inconsistent with the overall pattern of the transect, but the second sampling period was consistent. When the average for this site is deleted from the Luzon data, or if only data from the second period are included, the correlation becomes significant]. The correlation is significant for the Mindanao transect (r 2 = 0.91, P < 0.05; n = 5) and for the three data sets taken together (r 2 = 0.63, P < 0.05; n = 15).
body_text.section: Relative abundance patterns

body_text.text: The data presented above represent an unusual dataset: they were obtained in standardized fashion, are supplemented by more complete habitat descriptions and information on basic ecology than is typical for tropical mammals and are drawn from three study areas (Leyte, Luzon and Mindanao). Mindanao and Leyte have similar faunas, having been connected repeatedly as parts of a large Pleistocene island (Fig. 1) ; Luzon is almost entirely independent (i.e. less than 10% overlap in species present; Heaney, 1986) . These data thus should permit moderately robust tests of hypotheses of diversity patterns within communities of small mammals in the Philippines. As noted above, the 12 hypotheses range from descriptive and empirical to causal; their interrelatedness and lack of exclusive predictions are discussed below.
body_text.section: ASSESSMENT OF HYPOTHESES

body_text.text: H 0 : no significant variation is present The null hypothesis of no variation in species richness along elevational gradients in the Philippines is not rejected for the Leyte transect (no significant correlation is present), but is rejected for both Luzon and Mindanao (Figs 4 and 5, Table 1) , where there is a significant correlation between species richness and elevation. The mountain where the Leyte transect was conducted differs from the other two in having a maximum elevation of only ca. 1150 m. At the highest elevation, some aspects of mossy forest were present (heavy epiphyte load and thick organic soil), but temperatures were higher, tree height greater, and understorey vegetation less well developed than was the case in primary mossy forest on Luzon and Mindanao, and many elements of lowland forest were present: leaf size was larger than in typical mossy forest, and there was less development of the heavy moss layer that occurs typically above 1800 m in southern Luzon and above 2000 m on Mindanao (see descriptions in Heaney et al., 1989 Heaney et al., , 1999 Rickart et al., , 1993 . Thus, the null hypothesis is accepted only when there is not a full elevational gradient present (less than 1200 m), and is rejected in the three cases where the gradient includes lowland, montane and mossy forest, with elevations exceeding 1800 m.
body_text.section: ASSESSMENT OF HYPOTHESES

body_text.text: This hypothesis represents the most prevalent view of diversity patterns along elevational gradients, often phrased as an empirical pattern rather than a causal relationship (e.g. MacArthur, 1972, p. 211; Terborgh, 1977; Beehler, 1981; Brown & Gibson, 1983, p. 502; Graham, 1983 Graham, , 1990 Stevens, 1992; Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 Patterson et al., 1996 Patterson et al., , 1998 , although often combined with either H 4 or H 5 , both causal hypotheses described below. There is no decrease evident in any of the datasets presented here (Fig. 5) ; species richness shows either no pattern of variation (Leyte), an increase with elevation with a small decline near the peak (Luzon) or a curvilinear pattern (Mindanao and also Borneo; Md. Nor, 2001 ). The hypothesis therefore is rejected as an explanation of the patterns seen in Philippine small mammals.
body_text.section: H 1 : diversity decreases with increasing elevation

body_text.text: H 2 : diversity peaks in areas of community interdigitation Species richness may peak in areas where two distinctive communities (for example, a lowland and a highland community) interdigitate (Brown, 1995 (Brown, , 2000 or may peak at intermediate elevations when the elevational ranges of species are random (Colwell & Hurtt, 1994; Rahbek, 1997) . Quantitative assessment of this hypothesis is difficult, but visual assessment provides a clear indication of patterns. On Leyte (Fig. 3c) , where there is no significant correlation of species richness with elevation, there is no evidence of distinct small mammal communities. On Luzon (Fig. 3b) , maximum species richness occurs near the top of the mountain, and communities at progressively lower levels are attenuated versions of those at the next higher level; no evidence of distinct small mammal communities or interdigitation is present, and the hypothesis can be rejected for this transect.
body_text.section: H 1 : diversity decreases with increasing elevation

body_text.text: Along the transect on Mt Kitanglad, Mindanao (Figs 3a and 5 ), maximum species richness occurs at 2250 m, where the medium and high-elevation species all occur. This pattern is interpreted as providing some support for the hypothesis. When the summary data for all of Mindanao (Fig. 4) are considered, the same general pattern is evident: several species appear to be lowland species, several are mid-elevation species and several are high-elevation species. Maximum small mammal species richness occurs in the interval 1500 -2000 m where low, middle and high-elevation species all occur. However, most of the variation in species richness is due to the addition of species at middle and high elevation, rather than to interdigitation of two communities that are equal in richness, and there is gradual attenuation away from the elevation of maximum richness, rather than an abrupt shift from one small mammal community to another. Thus, either version of the hypothesis receives limited support in this case.
body_text.section: H 1 : diversity decreases with increasing elevation

body_text.text: In summary, this hypothesis receives generally weak support. It is rejected when maximum elevation is less than 2000 m (Leyte and Luzon), but may describe accurately a portion of the variation in species richness on the higher (2900 m) mountains on Mindanao (and Borneo; Md. Nor, 2001 ). These are places where there appear to be three fairly distinct communities of small mammals in low, middle, and high elevation forests, rather than one community (on Leyte) or two (lowland and highland, on Luzon). As a sole predictor, neither version of this hypothesis is adequate to account for observed variation in South-east Asian small mammals.
body_text.section: H 1 : diversity decreases with increasing elevation

body_text.text: Patterns of diversity have often been said to be influenced by natural disturbance, at a variety of scales. On a global scale, for example, the disturbance caused by glaciation at high latitudes has been cited as a cause for low diversity, due to enhanced extinction and slow recolonization, compared to the non-glaciated tropics (e.g. Fischer, 1960; MacArthur, 1972: 174; Wilson, 1974) . However, other authors have argued that smallscale disturbance may promote increased diversity, and there is no clear and consistent prediction that can be made (see review in Brown, 1988 ).
body_text.section: H 3 : diversity increases in areas of infrequent perturbation

body_text.text: In the case of Philippine small mammals, it is known that the climate of South-east Asia fluctuated frequently during the Pleistocene (Heaney, 1991a) , but those fluctuations influenced both lowland and highland vegetation. In general, temperatures declined during glacial episodes, causing elevational vegetation bands to move down to lower levels. On a shorter time scale, perturbations due to storms and earthquakes are probably common, but there is currently no reason to believe that the degree of disturbance is related to elevation. Thus, no clear prediction seems possible in this case, so no test can be made, and I suspect that this causal factor may not be relevant. I therefore reject this hypothesis for the case under study.
body_text.section: H 3 : diversity increases in areas of infrequent perturbation

body_text.text: Because we sampled only in primary or highquality secondary rain forest, and have dealt only with small mammals not subjected to any hunting, we have no data that relate to the impact of anthropogenic disturbance. However, preliminary data from other sites indicate that substantial anthropogenic habitat disturbance has a major impact (Heaney et al., 1989; Rickart, 1993 ).
body_text.section: H 3 : diversity increases in areas of infrequent perturbation

body_text.text: This hypothesis is derived from the familiar species-area curves that are a prominent part of the equilibrium model of MacArthur & Wilson (1967) . Several authors (e.g. MacArthur, 1972: 107, 211; Hunter & Yonzon, 1993; Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 have stated that declines in species richness may be caused by the decline in area in elevational bands as one ascends any mountain, due to ongoing colonization and extinction processes. This assumes the pattern of declining diversity described by H 1 , above; this hypothesis is thus one of several causal explanations for the purely descriptive pattern that is the basis for H 1 (see Williamson, 1988) .
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: There is some indirect support for this hypothesis. The modern islands that were part of Greater Mindanao during Pleistocene periods of low sea level currently exhibit a strong, significant correlation between species richness and island area (Heaney, 1986) . Moreover, if we compare the number of species within a single major habitat on these same islands, for example, lowland forest, we see a slight increase in species richness with increased island area (Heaney, 1986; Rickart et al., 1993) . However, most of the increase in species richness on these islands results from an increase in species richness at high elevations: it is principally the addition of a few hundred square kilometres of mossy forest that results in Mindanao, with about 99 000 km 2 , having more species than Maripipi, with an area of 22 km 2 , not the addition of a vastly greater area of lowland forest (Heaney, 1986; Rickart et al., 1993) .
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: With respect to the specific prediction that there will be a decrease in species richness along an elevational transect in proportion to the decrease in area at that elevation, the hypothesis is rejected at all three study areas: there is no pattern on low-lying Leyte, an increase with elevation on Luzon and a curvilinear pattern on Mindanao (as well as on nearby Borneo; Md. Nor, 2001 ). I thus reject this hypothesis as a sole explanation for the elevational patterns described in this paper.
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: H 5 : diversity increases with overall productivity This is probably the most widely cited causal hypothesis concerning variation in species richness that is cited in the ecological literature (e.g. MacArthur, 1972; Terborgh, 1977; Wright, 1983; Currie & Paquin, 1987; Brown, 1988; Rosenzweig, 1992; Ricklefs & Schluter, 1993; Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 . The standard assumption for tropical terrestrial habitats is that productivity is highest in wet lowland forest because of the combination of high temperature and high rainfall. Productivity is then predicted to decline with increasing elevation because of declining temperature and steady or declining rainfall.
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: However, as discussed under H 6 , there is increasing evidence that rainfall in tropical lowlands is highest and least seasonal at middle elevations (roughly 1500-2000 m), and current estimates of the pattern of productivity may need to be re-assessed on this basis. Moreover, several authors (Janzen, 1973; Janzen et al., 1976) have argued that net accumulation of production is highest at middle elevations. McCoy (1990) found a mid-elevation peak in both insect diversity and plant production along a transect in the southern Appalachian Mountains. Although he concluded that his data supported Janzen's hypothesis of a mid-elevation peak in productivity, he cautioned that the data were incomplete and tentative. Additionally, Tilman (1982) , Owen (1990) , and Rosenzweig (1992 Rosenzweig ( , 1995 Rosenzweig & Abramsky, 1993) have argued that the relationship between productivity and diversity is typically curvilinear, peaking somewhere near the mid-point of measurable levels experienced by the taxon or community under study.
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: If we accept the first set of assumptions regarding productivity (a progressive decline with elevation), then this hypothesis is rejected for small mammals in the Philippines and Borneo (Md. Nor, 2001) : as noted previously, there is no evidence of a pattern of declining species richness with increasing elevation (Figs 3, 4 and 5). Alternatively, if productivity peaks at middle elevations, as proposed by Janzen (1973) and tentatively supported by McCoy (1990) and Rahbek (1995) , then the hypothesis is supported by data presented here. The ambiguity about the elevational pattern of productivity poses a serious problem, however, and I conclude that support for the hypothesis must be regarded as ambiguous. Basic research on patterns of productivity is badly needed. An additional issue -that of the portion of total productivity accessible to a given group of species -is discussed under H 8 .
body_text.section: H 4 : diversity increases with increasing area

body_text.text: In general, rainfall should be highest at middle elevations because of adiabatic cooling processes: Beckinsale (1957; cited in Whitmore, 1984: 254) estimated an average increase of 100 mm per 30 m of elevation up to about the base of mossy forest (at ca. 1500 m), with a decline at higher elevations, and the limited available data support this (Terborgh, 1977; Coen, 1983; Hartshorn & Peralta, 1988; Pendry & Proctor, 1997; Rahbek, 1997) . In the Philippines, found that rainfall in forest at 865 m on Negros Island averaged nearly three times that at sea level (ca. 3100 mm vs. 1100 mm), and Balete & Heaney (1997) found that rainfall in forest at 1800 m on the transect site on Luzon was five times that at sea level.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: The specific predictions for this analysis are that species richness should increase progressively on Leyte (maximum rainfall at 1150 m, which is the peak of a mountain ridge) and Luzon (maximum rainfall at about 1800 m), just below the peak at 1966 m, and show a curvilinear pattern peaking at about 2000 m on Mindanao (which is the area of transition from montane to mossy forest). The prediction for Leyte is rejected (where there is no significant variation), but is accepted for the other cases. In other words, on islands where there is an elevational gradient that exceeds about 1800 m, the pattern of small mammal species richness is correlated with the amount of rainfall at any given elevation. I conclude that there is strong support for the hypothesis. H 7 : diversity increases with increasing abundance and/or biomass This hypothesis is sometimes made as an empirical observation, and often in the framework of conceptual issues of community dynamics (Graham, 1983 (Graham, , 1990 Terborgh, 1977) . It is often one of the most easily tested hypotheses concerning patterns of diversity because abundance and/or biomass are more easily measured than productivity, resource diversity, habitat complexity, etc.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: The pattern of small mammal relative abundance ( Fig. 6 ) is generally one of increasing relative abundance with increasing elevation up to about 2250 m. When data from all three transects are lumped, the correlation is significant (see Results); the correlation is not significant for the Leyte or Luzon transects taken separately, but is significant for the Mindanao transect taken separately. The correlation between abundance and species richness specifically predicted by the hypothesis (Fig. 7) is significant when all transects are lumped, but only the Mindanao transect shows a significant correlation when considered individually. I interpret these analyses as representing moderately strong support for the hypothesis. There is a consistent tendency for species richness in Philippine small mammal communities to be correlated with overall relative abundance in any given community: when the total number of individuals increases the number of species increases. H 8 : diversity increases with increasing resource diversity Discussions of differences in levels of biotic diversity often make mention of the possible impact of changes in the diversity of resources (especially food) that the organisms may use. This hypothesis is closely related to the hypothesis (H 5 ) that diversity is controlled by productivity (which in turn is related to H 6 concerning rainfall). In this case, the hypothesis focuses on that portion of the total productivity that is (or can be) used by a given set of species. Graham (1990), for example, argued that fruit and insect abundance probably decrease with increasing elevation in the Peruvian Andes, causing decreasing diversity and abundance of frugivorous and insectivorous birds and bats. Unfortunately, such discussions can easily become circular, because the presence of important resources may be identified only by the fact that the animals are using them, and use of the resources may then be used to explain the presence of the animals.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: In our studies, my colleagues and I have found evidence that the availability of a particular resource, soft-bodied soil invertebrates, especially earthworms, forms a resource that is heavily utilized by a distinctive subset of the small mammal community. In general, earthworms on high tropical mountains are scarce in the lowlands, increase somewhat in montane forest, are most abundant in mossy forest and decline in abundance as one progresses upward to the alpine zone (Collins, 1980; Fragoso & La velle, 1992) . We found a significant increase in earthworm abundance with increasing elevation at our Luzon site (rank correlation, r s = 1.0, P < 0.05; , with highest densities at 1350-1550 m (Fig. 8) . Several of the species of rodents at the Luzon site (Archboldomys luzonensis, Chrotomys gonzalesi, Rhynchomys isarogensis) feed heavily on such animals , and we have evidence of an equivalent set of vermivorous species at the Mindanao transect site. As shown in Figs 7 and 8 , the sites where earthworms are abundant have substantially higher levels of species richness than those where earthworms were scarce or virtually absent. The increase in species richness of small mammals is found even when relative density is held constant; in other words, addition of a certain food resource results in an increase in species richness, even if there is no increase in relative abundance.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: On this basis, I consider the hypothesis to be supported, but again emphasize the problem with identifying resources a priori and the potential for circularity in definitions. However, there is a further potential problem as well. It is clear that earthworms and other soft-bodied soil invertebrates are most abundant in areas with large amounts of organic matter in the soil, moderate temperatures and high rainfall (Fragoso & La velle, 1992) . On tropical mountains, it is declining temperatures that cause the production of large amounts of rain at middle elevations, and the combination of high rainfall and cool temperatures that result in the development of mossy forest. Thus, this hypothesis may be a result of the variation in rainfall and temperature discussed in H 6 above, i.e. a correlate of one of the proximate manifestations of the phenomenon that is described in that hypothesis, and thus not an independent hypothesis. H 9 : diversity increases with increasing habitat complexity This hypothesis is most often associated with MacArthur (1964 MacArthur ( , 1972 , usually refers to structural complexity (including foliage height diversity) and/or microhabitat diversity, and is often cited as a prime factor associated with variation in diversity (e.g. Karr & Roth, 1971; Patterson et al., 1989; Rahbek, 1995) , although Terborgh (1977) and Rosenzweig (1992) have suggested that the correlation may be either spurious or inadequate as a sole explanation. Unfortunately, this hypothesis often suffers in application from the same problems with circularity that were mentioned above: often only those aspects of habitat complexity that pertain to the study organism are measured, and this may yield a biased estimate of the total environmental complexity (Rosenzweig, 1992: 722) . In the case of South-east Asian small mammals, I would be reluctant to argue that lowland forest has less structural complexity than mossy forest, or vice versa. Both are highly complex, although in very different ways. In lowland forest, much of the structural complexity is in the canopy, and some is associated with the high total plant diversity with the attendant diversity in growth forms. In mossy forest most structural diversity is on the ground, where high plant diversity and extremely complex soil stratigraphy (often 2-5 m deep) provides a heterogeneous environment. Soil conditions in the lowlands are simpler than in the mossy forest, and canopy complexity is much lower in the mossy forest than in the lowlands. For tropical small mammals that live on the ground, it is not surprising that it is possible to define more habitat complexity in mossy forest than in lowland rain forest (e.g. Heaney et al., 1989; Patterson et al., 1989; .
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: For these reasons, testing this hypothesis is problematic. It is clear that species richness of Philippine small mammals is highest in areas of highest ground-level structural complexity (Rickart et al., , 1993 . However, because the functional definition of complexity is derived from their use of the habitat along the elevation gradient, I consider the hypothesis to be untestable in its general form. If the hypothesis were modified to the form 'species richness is highest in areas where the organisms under study are shown to use the greatest number of microhabitats', then the hypothesis could be accepted.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: H 10 : diversity increases with increasing habitat diversity This hypothesis differs from the previous one in its emphasis on the number of major types of habitats in a region, rather than on the complexity of microenvironments within a given type of habitat. In the Great Basin region of the south-western United States (Johnson, 1975; Newmark, 1986) and in south-eastern Australia (Fox, 1982; cited in Rosenzweig, 1992) , such measures of habitat diversity within isolated mountain ranges have been shown to be strongly correlated with mammalian and/or avian diversity. In the case of the Philippine Islands, the major natural habitat types are lowland, montane and mossy forest ( pine savanna, limestone forest and ultrabasic forest are present in other regions that we have not sampled). This hypothesis thus predicts that islands with all three major types of habitat would have more species than those with two types, etc.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: There is strong support for this hypothesis apparent in data on Philippine small mammals. Islands that contain only lowland forest lack many species that are present in montane and mossy forest on adjacent islands (e.g. Catanduanes Island, adjacent to the Mt Isarog transect area in southern Luzon: Heaney et al., 1991; Bohol Island, adjacent to Mindanao: Heaney, unpublished data) . On the larger islands it is clear that where the montane and mossy forests are best developed, small mammal species richness is highest. For example, on Luzon the mammal fauna in the Central Cordillera (maximum elevation = 2934 m) has many more species than the mountains of southern Luzon (where the highest forested mountain is Mt Isarog, at 1966 m; Heaney, 1986 Heaney, , 1993 Heaney et al., 1998 Heaney et al., , 1999 .

cite_spans.text: Bohol Island, adjacent to Mindanao: Heaney, unpublished data)

body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: However, it should be noted that our measure of habitat diversity is almost entirely dependent on elevation; in the Philippines, high mountains always have montane and mossy forest. Moreover, the presence of montane and mossy forest is determined by changes in temperature and precipitation that are, in turn, caused by variation in elevation. Thus, this hypothesis is not independent of several of the hypotheses discussed above. In addition, it is apparent that the area of the given habitat type (e.g. mossy forest) also has an impact; that is, it is not simply the presence of a habitat type that is important, but also its area. I conclude that support for this hypothesis is present but that it typically works in concert with other hypothesized factors.
body_text.section: H 6 : diversity increases with increasing rainfall

body_text.text: This hypothesis has been the focus of much ecological literature for several decades, with periods of waning and waxing support (e.g. papers in Cody & Diamond, 1975; Strong et al., 1984) . Little consensus seems to exist currently about the general impact of competition on diversity (e.g. Brown, 1988; papers in Ricklefs & Schluter, 1993) .
body_text.section: H 11 : diversity increases in areas of decreased competition

body_text.text: Although current evidence is limited and mainly anecdotal, my colleagues and I have concluded that ants may compete heavily with small mammals in the Philippines. We noted early in our studies that the frequency with which ants consumed the bait in our small mammal traps was near 100% in lowland forest, near zero in mossy forest, and that the frequency varied in a progressive fashion between the two extremes (Heaney & Rickart, unpublished data) . Data from the southern Luzon transect show that ant species richness and relative abundance are highest at the bottom of the transect and decrease steadily with increasing elevation (Samson et al., 1997) , and a similar pattern has been noted on Borneo (Collins, 1980) and in Costa Rica (Olson, 1994) . Ants are usually the first organisms to find and consume bait in the lowlands throughout the Philippines, and small mammal density is high only in places where ants are rare or absent. It has been suggested that arthropod competitors and prey species of ants exhibit increased abundance at high elevations because of the greatly reduced abundance of ants in cool, moist forest (Janzen, 1973; Stork & Brendell, 1990) . The hypotheses that ants and mammals compete for food resources, and that ants are the superior competitors when present, has been supported in recent studies in northern Borneo by Md. Nor (1997) .
body_text.section: H 11 : diversity increases in areas of decreased competition

body_text.text: Perhaps this working hypothesis should not have come as a surprise to us. There is abundant evidence that ants and small mammals compete heavily for food resources in the deserts of the south-western United States (Brown et al., 1986) , and ants are far more abundant and diverse in the lowland rain forests of Southeast Asia than in the south-western United States (Holldobler & Wilson, 1990) . I tentatively conclude that the hypothesis is supported by the current preliminary data, but also that much additional research is needed.
body_text.section: H 11 : diversity increases in areas of decreased competition

body_text.text: This hypothesis has been advanced primarily by palaeontologists and biogeographers (e.g. Janzen, 1967; Prance, 1982; papers in Myers & Giller, 1988) . It is the only one of the hypotheses presented here that deals with the evolutionary factors that are involved with generating diversity, rather than with ecological factors that may impose patterns on existing diversity (Heaney & Rickart, 1990; Rahbek, 1997; Heaney, 2000) .
body_text.section: H 12 : diversity is highest in areas that have experienced the highest rates of speciation

body_text.text: Data on Philippine mammals appear to support this hypothesis. For example, there are at least four cases in which species found in highland regions in southern Luzon have their closest relatives in the mountains of northern Luzon (Musser & Freeman, 1981; Rickart et al., 1998) . The mossy forest in which these species are now found is limited to the tops of mountains, and so they exist as isolated patches. However, during the periods of glacial advance in the Pleistocene, cooler conditions and lowered sea level allowed mossy forest habitat to descend in elevation throughout much of South-east Asia, so that the currently isolated populations probably were contiguous during those periods. Subsequent warming resulted in habitat shifts upward in elevation (Heaney, 1991a) , and consequently led to genetic isolation and speciation (Musser & Freeman, 1981; Heaney & Rickart, 1990; Rickart et al., 1998) . Species that live in the lowlands have not been isolated in this manner, and so had reduced opportunity for speciation. Thus, speciation on Luzon has been most frequent in high-elevation areas, where today the levels of species richness are highest. In other areas, over-water colonization has also contributed to speciation, so that vicariance of highland habitats should be viewed as one of several important processes that have contributed to speciation in Philippine small mammals (Heaney, 1986 (Heaney, , 1991b Heaney & Rickart, 1990) , not the sole process.
body_text.section: H 12 : diversity is highest in areas that have experienced the highest rates of speciation

body_text.text: The data summarized in Fig. 5 indicate that there is a fairly simple and consistent pattern of variation in species richness of small mammals along elevational gradients on old, species-rich islands. On mountains reaching about 3000 m, which allows full development of lowland, mont-ane and mossy forest, the pattern is curvilinear, peaking at or near the area where the transition occurs from montane to mossy forest. When maximum elevation is about 2000 m, only the increase phase of the curve is clearly evident. When the mountain peak is 1200 m or less, there is virtually no variation in species richness. Variation in species richness appears to be more strongly associated with the vegetation type at a given site than with elevation per se. For example, species richness peaks at or near the montane-mossy forest transition area, regardless of precise elevation (Fig. 5a) .
body_text.section: Variation in species richness of Philippine mammals

body_text.text: Correlated with variation in species richness is a pattern of increasing relative abundance from lowland forest to mossy forest. Current data sets on Philippine mammals lack information on relative abundance above 2250 m, but based on the strength of the curvilinear species richness pattern, I predict that future studies will find a decline in abundance that parallels the decline at upper elevations in species richness. The existence of these patterns would best be tested in places that have few species in common with southern Luzon and Mindanao, i.e. samples that are independent of our observations reported here. Such places in the Philippines would include northern Luzon (which has a fauna fairly distinct from that of southern Luzon), Mindoro and Palawan. Elsewhere in tropical Asia, transect studies on high mountains on Sulawesi, in Indochina and along the southern front of the Himalayas would be especially interesting because of their distinctive faunas. A preliminary analysis of rodents from New Guinea found a pronounced mid-elevation peak at ca. 1800 m (Rahbek, 1995) . A detailed, standardized transect on Mt Kinabalu, Borneo showed a pronounced mid-elevation peak in species richness (Md. Nor, 2001) , and a similar pattern of relative density (Md. Nor, 1997) .
body_text.section: Variation in species richness of Philippine mammals

body_text.text: While the focus of this study is on nonvolant small mammals, it should be noted that we also have documented patterns of diversity among one group of bats, the family of Old World fruit bats, Pteropodidae. In particular, we have studied the diverse small species (including roughly 15 species) which forage near the ground (and approach trees from below the canopy, rather than from above, as do the large 'flying foxes' of the genera Acerodon and Pteropus).
body_text.section: Variation in species richness of Philippine mammals

body_text.text: In contrast to the non-volant small mammals that are the focus of this paper, we have found a very consistent pattern of a negative correlation between species richness and elevation for these bats along the same transects where the non-flying mammals described in this paper were studied. Species richness among the fruit bats was often 7-8 in undisturbed lowland forest and 1-2 in mossy forest. Further, we found clear evidence of decreasing abundance with increasing elevation, and a significant correlation between species richness and overall relative abundance (Heaney et al., 1989; Heaney & Rickart, 1990; Rickart et al., 1993; Rickart, 1993; Utzurrum, 1995; Heaney et al., 1999) . Although I will make no further mention of this group of mammals in this paper, it should be kept in mind that the data and discussion presented in this paper refer to a specific group of mammals, and that the reader should recognize that different groups of mammals may show different patterns along a given transect, as is the case for the mammals in Oaxaca, Mexico studied by Sánchez-Cordero (2001).
body_text.section: Variation in species richness of Philippine mammals

body_text.text: In spite of the pervasiveness of the assumption that maximum biotic diversity occurs in lowland rain forest, many authors have suggested that mid-elevations peaks are common in certain communities (reviewed by Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 . This pattern has often been found in tropical leaf-litter and soil invertebrate communities at locations around the globe (Janzen, 1973; Janzen et al., 1976; Gagne, 1979; McCoy, 1990; Olson, 1994) . Studies of individual taxa have found similar patterns (Melastomataceae in Peru: Terborgh, 1977 ; ferns on Borneo: Parris et al., 1992 ; orchids on Borneo: Wood et al., 1993; Lepidoptera in Indo-Australia: Holloway et al., 1990; beetles on Sulawesi: Hammond, 1990; Stork & Brendell, 1990; Andean birds: Rahbek, 1997; non-volant small mammals: Md. Nor, 2001; Rickart, 2001; Sánchez-Cordero, 2001 ). Olson (1994) suggested that the failure of some surveys of tropical arthropod diversity to detect a mid-elevation peak is due to small sampling area, although he noted that current data are limited. McCoy (1990) also argued that different sampling regimes may determine the outcome of insect diversity surveys, a point also emphasized by Rahbek (1995) .

body_text.section: The mid-elevation peak as a general pattern

body_text.text: Several authors (Janzen et al., 1976; Terborgh, 1977) have argued that net primary productivity may actually be highest at intermediate elevations, rather than in the lowlands, because of increased and relatively aseasonal rainfall (Coen, 1983; Hartshorn & Peralta, 1988; Rahbek, 1995 Rahbek, , 1997 . Leaf-fall may be greatest in montane forests (Leigh, 1975) , and there is some evidence that tree species richness may be highest at intermediate elevations (Proctor et al., 1988; Heaney & Proctor, 1990 ). However, this remains controversial. Gentry (1982, 1988) showed strong evidence of a correlation between precipitation and species richness of all large (>2.5 cm) woodystemmed Neotropical plants; however, he also demonstrated a regular decline in species richness of these plants along the elevational gradient, and noted specifically the absence of a mid-elevation bulge along the Andean front from the lowlands to over 3000 m.
body_text.section: The mid-elevation peak as a general pattern

body_text.text: Given the current controversy, it is apparent that the existence and generality of the midelevation peak can be tested only by a series of detailed transect surveys along high tropical mountains. Such studies must incorporate information on many taxa in order to test the general phenomenon; studies of individual taxa will be unlikely to resolve the issue. A comparison of various taxa that show different patterns may be especially important, since these may allow finer resolution of precise causal factors than studies of single taxa.
body_text.section: The mid-elevation peak as a general pattern

body_text.text: Several hypotheses are rejected in this paper as potential explanations for the patterns documented in Philippine small mammals; these are H 0 (the null hypothesis of no variation), H 1 (diversity decreasing with increasing elevation), H 3 (diversity decreases with increasingly severe perturbations) and H 4 (diversity declines with declining area at a given elevation). Additionally, several others are more ambiguous but generally inadequate: H 2 (diversity peaks in areas of community interdigitation), H 5 (diversity increases with overall productivity) and H 9 (diversity increases with increasing habitat complexity). One might argue that the data presented here have falsified some of these hypotheses, and that they should be discarded.
body_text.section: Can any hypotheses be entirely rejected and/or discarded?

body_text.text: However, this simplistic approach would not do justice to the many studies that have found support for the given hypotheses. There undoubtedly are places where there is no significant variation along a given transect (H 0 ), as was the case along our Leyte transect, and there are many cases of declining diversity with increasing elevation among birds (Terborgh, 1977; Goodman & Gonzales, 1990; Graham, 1990; Hunter & Yonzon, 1993; Goodman, 1996) and bats (Graham, 1983; Heaney et al., 1989; Utzurrum, 1995; Patterson et al., 1996 Patterson et al., , 1998 and these cases are consistent with the hypotheses of declining area (H 4 ) and declining productivity (H 5 ). Increases in diversity associated with community interdigitation (H 2 ) are so well-known that the term 'ecotone' is nearly always associated with increased diversity, at least on a local scale (e.g. Ricklefs, 1979: 672; Brown & Gibson, 1983: 93) . Similar arguments could be advanced for the other hypotheses that were not supported in the case of Philippine small mammals. It would appear that all of the hypotheses presented here represent phenomena that are real in nature. The relevant issues are, first, which hypotheses help to understand a given instance (e.g. small mammals in the Philippines), and second, on what set of organisms and under what circumstances a given phenomenon (described by given hypothesis) has an evident impact. In other words, rather than focusing on accepting or rejecting simplistic, unifactorial hypotheses, we need to determine the circumstances under which the various causal factors are important, how they interact and how they can be combined in to a more comprehensive and general multi-factorial model (see also Brown, 1988; Rahbek, 1997) .
body_text.section: Can any hypotheses be entirely rejected and/or discarded?

body_text.text: The first step in developing such a general model is the recognition that many of the phenomena described in the hypotheses listed above are not independent (Rahbek, 1995 (Rahbek, , 1997 . In the case of Philippine small mammals, the following scenario is illustrative.
body_text.section: Interdependence of hypotheses

body_text.text: The condensation that produces rainfall is caused by decreasing temperature in an air mass.
body_text.section: Interdependence of hypotheses

body_text.text: Because air masses cool as they rise over mountains, rainfall increases with increasing elevation up to the point at which the air mass is able to go around the remaining peaks, rather than over them; from that point upwards, rainfall declines. Declining temperature permits organic detritus to accumulate faster than bacteria and invertebrates can break it down. Deep soil, high rainfall and moderate temperatures at middle elevations create optimal conditions for soft-bodied soil invertebrates. The decline in temperature and increasing rainfall create conditions that are unsuitable for ants, which are highly successful competitors under conditions of high temperature and moderate to low rainfall in the lowlands. The variation in temperature, rainfall and soil conditions create conditions that favour different groups of plants at various elevations, and these form moderately distinct types of vegetation along the elevational gradient, but grade into one another in some places. Terrestrial small mammals are able to use the deep, complex soil and litter layers for refuge, and encounter abundant soil invertebrates on which to feed. The abundance of this resource allows them to reach high densities, and allows them to specialize on food resources that are highly stable over time because of the stability of the climate, thus permitting many species to coexist. Global fluctuations in climate cause the conditions that characterize mossy forest to shift in elevation, causing expansion at some times and contraction and isolation at other times, resulting in many opportunities for speciation, relative to conditions in the lowlands.
body_text.section: Interdependence of hypotheses

body_text.text: This speculative but quite plausible scenario demonstrates that nearly all of the hypotheses can be drawn into a more general, interactive model that recognizes the interplay of all of the phenomena that the hypotheses represent. For other organisms, different scenarios would have to be drawn, but it is not the development of such scenarios that I argue for. Rather, I believe that the development of an explicit, testable multifactorial model is necessary, one that recognizes the existence of multiple causal factors operating at different scales among different groups of organisms. Such a model would have to recognize the fact that organisms differ in their ability to utilize various resources and in their response to various climatic parameters, and so each would be influenced differently at a given site with a given set of resource and climatic parameters. Thus, I concur strongly with the call by Lawton (1996) , Ricklefs & Schluter (1993) and Rahbek (1995 Rahbek ( , 1997 for synthesis, integration and recognition of the common ground that exists among all of the many hypotheses concerning patterns of biological diversity.
